news.n_title: Student shows off his Indian roots by flaunting the tricolour at graduation ceremony in New York. Internet says Bravo
news.n_description: Shared on Twitter by Brigadier Hardeep Singh Sohi, the post shows the ex-army man’s son draped in his graduation robes. But apart from the vivid purple robe, he also wore the Indian tricolour at the ceremony

n_offline_data.no_desc_withouthtml:
Tesla and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk’s college sweetheart Jennifer Gwynne has auctioned off her photos with Musk off late.  These photos show Musk as a 20-year-old college student having fun around the University of Pennsylvania campus. Gwynne, who currently lives with her stepson in South Carolina, is selling these photos via RR Auction to raise money for her stepson’s tuition fee. 

Sharing a picture of Musk as a 23-year-old at the University of Pennsylvania, Gwynne said, “Elon was usually very reserved, but occasionally he would just get very silly and want me to laugh along with him. So I decided to document him actually smiling.” 

She said their romance was sweet but there was not much affection or ‘PDA’ as Musk largely resisted it. It was during this time that Musk’s mother and supermodel Maye Musk and his siblings had got to know about his plans to make electric vehicles. She also said, “Timeline note here– Elon talked about electric cars being the way of the future back in 1994. 

He said [EV] was going to be [at the] forefront of the movement and I never doubted that he would be there – he was so matter-of-fact and so sure that electric cars were coming. 

So, honestly, for the last 25 years, I knew Tesla was going to work, that it was going to be successful. There is something so very infectious about Elon’s confidence and clarity.”After graduating from Penn with BA in physics and Bachelor of Science degree in economics from Wharton school, Musk went to Stanford University for PhD in materials science. 

Musk left Stanford after two days to launch his first start-up amid the internet boom.

The boar has also cleare issuing of 1.75 crore addiional equity stock optons exercisble into equivalen number of equity shares fully paid up of Rs 10 each, in addition to residual/remaining options which remain ungranted under ESOP 2018.

The bank's board also cleared the appointment of two independent directors -- Gopal's Jain, Managing Partner and Founder Gaja Capital, and Sivakumar Gopalan, Faculty of the Department of Computer Science and Engineerin, IIT Bombay.The private sector lender posted Rs 201 crore profit for the quarter ended June 30, 2022 against a net loss of Rs 459 cror in the year-ago period.

news.n_title: Shraddha murder horror returns: Woman, son chop husband into pieces, store in fridge in Delhi, held
news.n_description: A woman and her son have been arrested for allegedly murdering her husband and chopping his body into pieces before disposing them off in Delhi's Pandav Nagar neighbourhood. The killing has similarities to the Shraddha Walkar murder.

n_live_blog_content.n_amp_description:

The Union government will not make the mask mandatory for now as India logs 163 fresh cases of Covid amid an explosive surge in China. However, as part of the advisory, people have been asked to wear masks and follow Covid protocols, but the mask mandate will not be enforced for now.

RRR mania has kickstarted in Japan! SS Rajamouli, Ram Charan and Jr NTR have reached there for the release of their film. RRR will hit the big screen in Japan on October 21, 2022. Ahead of the film's release, the RRR trio promoted their film with the Japanese media. Photos of Rajamouli, Ram Charan and Jr NTR have already gone viral on social media. And now, Ram Charan shared his dapper look on Instagram. In the pictures, the actor can be seen happily posing for the camera.

RAM CHARAN SHARES HIS DAPPER LOOK

Ram Charan took to his official Instagram handle and shared his photos. The actor didn't give away much about his appearance in the caption and simply wrote 'Japan' with a heart emoji. If you haven't seen his photos yet, check them out right below:

 
 
 
 
View this post on Instagram
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

A post shared by Ram Charan (@alwaysramcharan)

Ram Charan was also spotted interacting with his fans in Japan. The actor even posed for selfies with them. The actor's wife, Upasana, has accompanied him to the grand premiere of RRR.

ABOUT RRR

Directed by SS Rajamouli, RRR is a fictional story based on the lives of  Alluri Seetharama Raju and Komaram Bheem, played by Ram Charan and Jr NTR. The film also featured Shriya Saran, Alia Bhatt and Ajay Devgn. The film was released in cinemas on March 25, 2022.

n_offline_data.no_desc_withouthtml:
In Juhu, Mumbai - pin code 400 049 - stand two edifices that must count as the mecca of Indian cinema. The structures themselves inspire no great awe, betray no special aura beyond what any bungalow in an upmarket neighbourhood may be accused of exuding. But like with any shrine, it’s about who resides within. Generations of filmgoers have been so enamoured of the man—so filled by a strange energy at his mere appearance on that screen on which their desires are projected — that he seems to approach a numinous stature. Here, on the road outside, vehicles slow down so passengers can quickly take photos, even if it is just a shot of the wooden gate. Pedestrians refresh themselves with water from a giant earthen vessel and prayers begin for a miracle sighting. Vigilant safari-clad men blow their shrill whistles to ensure there’s no crowding. It’s pointless. There’s always one, especially in the evenings. From 1976 to 2000s, this scene used to unfold at Prateeksha, now it is Jalsa. There’s also Janak nearby, a kind of workspace, which has escaped attention. Not surprising perhaps, because it’s at the primary abode that the devout feel the magic of nearness. The hero they have come to worship...He Lives Here. And his name is Amitabh Bachchan.

Sharing a tender moment with his father, the renowned Hindi poet Harivansh Rai Bachchan, Mumbai, 1997; (Photo: Bandeep Singh) | In a shoot for an interview in India Today in 2004, when our photographer Bandeep Singh asked Bachchan about the influence his father had on his life, he said, “For me, my father was a colossus. If I can read all that he has written in my lifetime, I’d have attained salvation"

It’s a Sunday evening, a day when Bachchan, if he’s in town and in the mood, is known to greet and wave at his fans. A quick sampling of the crowd reveals something about the man—the way his force-field has overflowed the usual embankments of space and time. There are fans of all age groups. And the catchment area is also pan-national, not usual for a Hindi film personality. Jessy and Smita, a lawyer and a teacher, respectively, are from Kerala. They have ditched their friends in Juhu beach in the hope of sighting the man they adored in Piku. “There’s something very interesting about him,” says Jessy, as she makes her way to Prateeksha from Jalsa. Standing across the road from them is Vikas Singh, a doctor from Patna, who refers to Bachchan as a “superhero”. Singh’s words are tinged with awe as he shares his long list of favourite Bachchan films. “He is a league apart,” he says. “So many have gone, but he is still performing.”

Deewaar, Sholay, Trishul, Don, Muqaddar Ka Sikandar and Kaala Patthar changed not just Amitabh’s fate but the very heart and culture of Hindi cinema

The ‘still’ is pertinent because Bachchan turns 80 on October 11. He made his feature film debut at the age of 27. A different epoch: the Beatles were still playing, a fledgling Doordarshan had not even reached Bombay, and women in Hindi films were still cycling to picnics with their hair in beehive buns, singing pretty songs. Fifty-three years later, all that is water down the bridge, but he is ‘still’ on top of his game. So much so that he puts far younger peers to shame with his sheer, jaw-dropping volume of work, as with his still-undimmed work ethic.

But even a phenomenon has to start somewhere. A quiet, dignified entry in a film called Saat Hindustani (1969) performed that historic function, but done by the old writer-director Khwaja Ahmad Abbas—the man behind Dharti Ke Lal (1946) and many of Raj Kapoor’s films—his idealistic vein also kept it off-Broadway, so to speak. The mainstream largely shunned the tall, gangly youth for a few more years, with only a trickle of minor films coming his way. Navin Nishchol, who debuted a year after Bachchan, rose to stardom faster—and got paid more. It was still a world made for romantic heroes with khubani ka meetha faces. So nobody could have anticipated what happened thereafter.

A supporting role in Hrishikesh Mukherjee’s Anand (1971) was a bend in the road—even next to the bravura, author-backed role of superstar Rajesh Khanna, Bachchan’s quiet intensity filtered through. Filmmakers slowly learnt to harness that flame. Finally, Zanjeer (1973) scaled that up to full-scale arson. Bachchan’s honest cop, tormented by inner and outer demons, burst forth on the Seventies with such a primal force that it caught the zeitgeist. It was a time of inner ferment for the nation and its youth, beginning to chafe in such rage at the corrupt, stagnant system that the Emergency was soon imposed in a vain bid to bottle it up. Bachchan’s ‘Angry Young Man’ became the very embodiment of that larger storm. And stayed there, like a one-man forest fire, through the decade and beyond. With films like Deewaar, Sholay, Trishul, Don, Muqaddar Ka Sikandar and Kaala Patthar, what changed was not merely Amitabh Bachchan’s fate, but the very heart and culture of Hindi cinema. Its very tone and tenor. Through those times, he towered over everything precisely because he had co-authored those times, like some deity in an act of Creation.

For those who came in late, there were more unbelievable twists in the plot—careening between the demigodly status and destitution. A bout of injury and ill health, a diversion to politics that ended as ignominiously as it started gloriously, a filmography that sputtered down to largely inconsequential films that sought to ride on his past popularity without ever recreating anything like his past incandescence, and then a fateful turn to business. A company was set up that dared to think big but managed to end small...very small. As the century wound down, the Amitabh Bachchan Corporation Limited was winding up in bankruptcy—and taking down a human piece of history with it. Then as the clock struck the new millennium, the pendulum swung again to the other side. A remarkable second innings started. Kaun Banega Crorepati (KBC), a quiz show on Star TV, got Bachchan right into drawing rooms...and people reacted as if divinity was paying a visitation in humanised form. And slowly, the films started striking a second burst of efflorescence too—like a Nilgiri kurinji plant flowering after a gap of 14 years. Why is Amitabh Bachchan a piece of living history? Because that phase, again unbelievably, is still with us.

The Marathon Man

For, there was no escaping Bachchan in 2022—as he was going on 80. In April release Runway 34, he was playing a no-nonsense head of the Aircraft Accident Investigation Bureau, grilling and lecturing a pompous pilot (Ajay Devgn, a next-generation hero who’s himself no spring chicken now). In September, Bachchan was a wise, sword-wielding mentor in Brahmastra. The film, having earned Rs 247 crore nationwide, is still running in cinema halls. But he has another one slated for the marquee—Goodbye. His co-star is Rashmika Mandanna of Pushpa fame, who is just a year senior to Bachchan’s granddaughter, Navya Naveli Nanda. Audiences will see him on the big screen in November too, in Sooraj Barjatya’s Uunchai, alongside Anupam Kher and Boman Irani. And he’s still on the small screen, clocking in 14 hours a day to shoot KBC, which is in its 14th season. With this kind of a chock-a-block calendar, one would think this is the 1970s-80s, with Bachchan working at such a pace he hardly had time for family.

It was in 1980, when he was at the summit and at his prolific best, that India Today featured him on the cover and christened him ‘The One-Man Industry’. Perhaps too happening to be considered an ‘institution’ yet, like older thespians like Dilip Kumar would have been then. But with a good ensemble of films that showcased an eclectic actorly repertoire, comparisons may have started getting made. Two years later, the two came face to face in Shakti. But four decades later, Bachchan’s career has outlasted other thespian luminaries not just by the sheer volume of films he has done—over 180 and counting, excluding the innumerable ones as narrator—but also with the range of his work. Now, though he’s still happening, no one would hesitate to confer on him nobler encomiums—like ‘the legend’, or ‘an institution’. His iconic status, as well as his ease before the camera, is precisely what makes him one of the most-trusted names among brands who seek his face and, more significantly, that deep baritone to sell their products and services. The Duff & Phelps Celebrity Brand Valuation Study of 2021 ranked Bachchan sixth, with a brand value of $54.2 million. Even governments have counted on him for their public service advertising campaigns like ‘Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao’ or to urge citizens to be cautious during the Covid-19 pandemic.

Four decades on, Bachchan’s career has outlasted other thespian luminaries not just by the volume of his films but also the range of work

Age usually slows a person, but in Bachchan’s case, his zeal to perform and engage with his fans—whether via his films or many social media accounts, including the blog Bol Bachchan—is untouched by senescence. As soon as the second lockdown ended, eager to face the camera again, he called his go-to photographer Avinash Gowariker over.

“Our country has seen many superstars, but stardom with his kind of longevity is a rarity and I think it will be very difficult to match up to it,” says Dangal maker Nitesh Tiwari, who directed Bachchan in Bhootnath Returns and also worked with him in the KBC ad campaigns. Like many directors of today, Tiwari grew up on a healthy diet of Bachchan films. He wept for his hero at the end of Muqaddar ka Sikandar; he smiled when he couldn’t get tickets to Hum in Gwalior...because it meant Bachchan had finally had a hit after a bad run; and he was “nervous as hell” when, as executive creative director of Leo Burnett, he sat in Bachchan’s office in Janak to narrate the “Koi sawal chhota nahin hota” promotional campaign for KBC. His mother and her family, he notes, were more proud when they learned he was working with Bachchan than when he got into IIT Bombay. “A childlike curiosity keeps him going,” adds Tiwari. “He approaches a 30-second commercial or a two-and-a-half-hour film with the same rigour.”

Almost everyone who has worked with him credits Bachchan’s long shelf-life to his discipline or “anushaasan”, as his character in Mohabbatein would say. Leena Yadav, who directed him in Teen Patti, recalls how she’d tell the four newcomers in the film—which included Shraddha Kapoor—to seek inspiration from his sense of punctuality and preparedness. In the unlikely event of him running late, he is known to message and inform the director directly and expects an acknowledgement, as Tiwari would learn one day. Then there’s the humility. Nothing holds him back from setting aside years of experience and countless accolades to learn from new creators, regardless of their age. Filmmakers mention how he is totally open to retakes and suggestions. And yet, there’s a dignified kind of gravitas. “Ek thahraav bhi hai,” as Leena Yadav puts it. “He doesn’t underline his own presence, but then you can’t help not underline it. However humbly he is sitting there, he is Amitabh Bachchan.”

The Mythical Being

This aura, what R. Balki calls the “myth and mystique”, also transmits itself to viewers. And that’s why audiences cannot get enough of him. Balki, one of his most frequent collaborators in the past 15 years and who has written yet another cameo for him in the 2023 release Ghoomer, puts his finger too on that X-factor. It’s born of “his effort and the effort of the world which has preserved the myth”, he says. “What has happened due to it is that we are not able to fathom this entity, which will never come again. Cinema is never going to have stars like Bachchan because they (the present lot) are too accessible and don’t have that kind of bigness.” The enigma endures, especially since Bachchan has cut down his media interactions in the past decade. Even those who worked with him in the early stages of his career, like renowned screenwriter-lyricist Javed Akhtar, who co-wrote some of Bachchan’s most iconic roles in Zanjeer and Deewar, say, “Anybody who claims to know Amitabh Bachchan is lying. He is a very reserved and private person.”

That trait was indeed partly why a perception was fostered of a man who came out of no- where to kick down the doors of Hindi cinema. But of course, Amitabh did not come out of nowhere. Born to renowned Hindi poet Harivansh Rai Bachchan (né Srivastava; 1907-2003) and his Sikh wife Teji, a psychology professor and social activist, there was quite a bit of old-style legacy there—including a storied bond with the Nehru-Gandhi family. Nehru had sponsored Harivansh Rai’s senior doctoral thesis at Cambridge, and on his return, he had joined as head of the External Affairs Ministry’s Hindi division. Amitabh and his brother Ajitabh had thus been friends with the Gandhi siblings—Rajiv and Sanjay—since childhood. In fact, in January 1968, a year before Amitabh debuted in cinema, as Sonia Maino arrived from Italy to marry Rajiv Gandhi, it was Amitabh who received her. And she stayed at the Bachchan residence in Delhi for a few weeks. But while that family friendship was to sour, his own poet-father would remain an endless inspirational resource for Amitabh.In a shoot for an interview to India Today in 2004, when our photographer Bandeep Singh asked him about that influence, he said, “For me, my father was a colossus. If I can read all that he has written in my lifetime, I’d have attained salvation.” That inner quietude—which forms something like a screen between him and the world and often stumps even film industry colleagues—is not surprising then.

If there’s one platform where audiences come closest to knowing Bachchan, it is KBC. On it, you see him switch from being the teasing paternal figure prodding a contestant on marriage to the empathetic man when a woman bemoans not being allowed to study further. He also discloses memorable instances from his personal life and anecdotes from his storied career. The show, famously, arrived at a time when Bachchan was struggling for financial security and professional relevance in a film industry that was evolving—the multiplex boom had encouraged the rise of independent cinema that deviated from formula, his old mainstay. His son, Abhishek, had made his debut with Refugee (2000); Shah Rukh Khan was the man of the moment, with the other Khans—Aamir and Salman—giving him a run for his money. At 59, Bachchan was very cognisant of the fact that attempting to stay the commercial Bollywood hero—as with the ill-fated Mrityudaata—was pointless; those days were over and he needed substantial parts that wouldn’t diminish his legend. But in showbiz, out of sight equals out of mind. So playing “the friend, philosopher and guide” on KBC was a gamechanger, as Sameer Nair, then executive vice-president, programming, at Star Plus and a forever Bachchan fan, puts it. “When the show came on at 8 pm, the remote was controlled by parents who were Bachchan fans while the kids were fans of the Khans,” notes Nair. But soon, sporting a grey French beard, seamlessly shuttling between fluent Hindi and English and exuding charm and positivity, Bachchan expanded his fan base among the young.

If there’s one platform where audiences come closest to getting to know Bachchan, it’s KBC. Here, he shares vignettes of his life and career

It was also a period when he would increase his advertising portfolio and come into contact with a new breed of creators like Shoojit Sircar and Balki, who’d later give him a gift every actor craves for: the opportunity to reinvent himself. Sircar’s first film with Bachchan, Shoebite, hasn’t yet seen the light of day, but it led to one of the most fruitful collaborations in his second inning. “We have that kind of faith in each other that we can talk about anything,” Sircar once told india today in an interview. “I have no agenda with him and he recognises that. As a personality, he is intimidating but, inside, he is an innocent child who just wants to act.”

Bachchan’s talent, in this latter phase, was also very much about how he moulded it. Luck played a role, too, as a new breed of filmmakers emerged, with offbeat narratives scripted with Bachchan in mind—Rakeysh Omprakash Mehra’s Aks, Sanjay Leela Bhansali’s Black, Balki’s Paa, to name a few. The actor, in turn, pounced on those scripts with the same intensity he would have had for essaying Gogol’s Mayor back in Sherwood College. And, in the process, he got reintroduced to a new audience. For the millennials, he wasn’t “the angry young man” they had seen on satellite TV in the 1990s but the strict principal of Mohabbatein, the flirt of Kabhi Alvida Naa Kehna, the imposing politician of Sarkar, the arrogant chef of Cheeni Kum, the tenacious lawyer of Pink.

The First Wave

Aysha Iqbal Viswamohan, professor, film studies, IIT Madras, is one of the many cinephiles who observed the Bachchan ‘first wave’ up close. That decade-long golden streak beginning with Zanjeer that would lead his contemporary Jeetendra to remark that he was Hindi cinema’s “No. 1 to 10 star”. Viswamohan attributes the actor’s mass appeal to his ability to “lend a touch of authenticity” to the innumerable working-class heroes he played. Throughout, Bachchan was changing the definition of what constituted a mainstream Hindi film hero. Says Viswamohan: “He was a perfect antidote to the heightened romanticism of Rajesh Khanna. His unique embodiment of hegemonic masculinity fitted Salim-Javed’s conception of a lone-ranger, urban cowboy, vigilante hero as popularised by Hollywood stars like Clint Eastwood and Steve McQueen. To this, he added a style of brooding intensity that harked back to Dilip Kumar. The result of this concoction was a new kind of morally ambiguous hero that suited the temper of the changing times.”

Almost everyone who has worked with him credits Bachchan’s long shelf-life to his discipline. And his humility. He’s forever open to retakes and suggestions

But like in his new phase, Bachchan was bold with his choices at his peak, not allowing himself to be boxed in. The angry young man also dabbled memorably with romance (Kabhi Kabhie, Silsila), comedy (Chupke Chupke, Amar Akbar Anthony, Mr Natwarlal, Namak Halal), and served up a more sensitive side in films like Alaap (1977) and Manzil (1979), even if they weren’t received as well as his action-heavy dramas. It’s this variegated filmography that led to diehard fans like S.M.M. Ausaja, author, film historian and archivist, who started collecting Bachchan memorabilia in 1981 when still in school. Ausaja will admit that his star wasn’t infallible. “It’s frivolous to say he hasn’t done bad films or there was no fall. But even in those, there are moments where he stood out,” says Ausaja. Today, Ausaja sits on 5,000 items—posters, film stills, lobby cards, magazines, slides, transparencies, books, postcards. The labour of his love will make its way into The Bachchans, a four-kg, 600-page coffeetabler chronicling three generations of the family, beginning with Bachchan’s grandfather, Pratap Narain Srivastava in Pratapgarh, and ending with his daughter-in-law Aishwarya Rai Bachchan. With Bachchan having already launched his two other books, Ausaja is hopeful his idol will do the honours this time too in December.

Making/ Preserving History

As his cult grew, Bachchan became distinctly aware of his own distinct place in Indian cinema. Filmmaker, archivist and restorer Shivendra Singh Dungarpur, who founded the Film Heritage Foundation of which Bachchan is a brand ambassador, notes that the actor preserved 35mm celluloid of his films like Mili, Chupke Chupke, Zanjeer and Don in an air-conditioned room at his Juhu house. Audiences in 18 cities can watch 11 of his 1970s and ’80s classics from October 8-11 at PVR cinemas in an FHF retrospective called Bachchan: Back to the Beginning. If there’s one living actor who merits a retrospective, it is of course Bachchan. With tickets priced at Rs 80, Dungarpur says most shows are sold out—and even actors are calling seeking tickets for Amar Akbar Anthony. “There’s nobody who bridges the past, present and future of Indian cinema better than Mr Bachchan,” says Dungarpur, whose foundation is entrusted with the Bachchan archive. “He has preserved the past and continues to preserve the present, as evident by his numbered tweets. Most people exist and allow things to happen [to them], but he is aware of the world he lives in.” He writes his own tweets and blog entries. Beyond technology, Bachchan has kept up with the times sartorially too, carrying off hoodies and sweatpants or blingy brooches with elan. He recently even introduced a new line of perfumes.

But since 1999, his focus has been acting. Having learned from the ABCL debacle, AB Corp has stuck to co-producing a few films. Next year, audiences will see three generati­ons of Bachchans. His grandson, Agastya Nanda, makes his debut in Zoya Akhtar’s Netflix film The Archies; son Abhishek will feature in Balki’s Ghoomer and Amitabh, at the grand age of 80, has the multilingual Project K alongside Deepika Padukone and Prabhas.

In 1997, after his maiden home production Mrityudaata flopped, india today wrote, “The question is: where does Bachchan go from here?” Little did we, or anyone, know that 25 years later, we’d “still” be talking about him. His name means ‘the light that won’t fade’. Fittingly, thus, it illuminates darkened cinema halls, living room televisions and now our mobile screens. That’s how long his reign has been. The answer to that question, though? Here it goes: Amitabh Bachchan is here to perform until his last breath. And the world is a better place for it.

news.n_title: Rewa Ultra Mega Solar & Hydropower Plans for Solar & Hydropower in Madhya Pradesh, India
news.n_description: AI Generated  Pumped-storage hydroelectricity and solar energy are becoming increasingly popular sources of renewable energy in Madhya Pradesh, India. The Rewa Ultra Mega Solar project is the world's largest solar power plant, and hydropower has been used for the Bhoj Metro.

n_offline_data.no_desc_withouthtml:
AI Generated Pumped-Storage Hydroelectricity: Energy with Unprecedented Flexibility

The turning of the century has ushered in an era of unprecedented energy consumption. In turn, this has led to the rise of efficient, cost-effective renewable energy sources. Among these renewable energy sources, pumped-storage hydroelectricity stands out for its unique flexibility. In this article, we’ll explore what this energy source is, its applications, and details of a game-changing pilot project implemented in the Indian state of Madhya Pradesh.

What is Pumped-Storage Hydroelectricity?

Pumped-storage hydroelectricity is a process of generating energy using the water cycle. Water stored in higher elevation reservoirs is pumped and released to the lower elevation one through turbines valves. During the process, the water’s kinetic energy is converted into electricity. This electricity can then be used by customers or consumed by the power grid.

When the demand for electricity is low, the turbines are switched on along with the pumps to fill the higher elevation reservoir. This ensures that there is enough power available to meet the electricity needs when the demand increases. So, pumped-storage hydroelectricity is a system that can be used in an energy-efficient manner.

Solar Power in India

Renewable energy sources such as solar and wind power are gaining traction in India. Madhya Pradesh, a state located in Central India, has pioneered the development of renewable energy sources. In 2018, the state of Madhya Pradesh installed the world’s largest solar power project, the Rewa Ultra Mega Solar Plant. This project can generate 750 megawatts of electricity, nearly 10 percent of India’s total solar power output.

The Bhoj Metro, a pump-to-storage hydropower project, is another pioneering example of renewable energy development in Madhya Pradesh. This ambitious project is the first of its kind in India. The project seeks to use a combination of solar and hydropower to generate electricity throughout the state.

Combining Pumped-Storage Hydroelectricity and Solar Power

The Bhoj Metro is breaking new grounds in its innovative combination of pumped-storage hydroelectricity and solar power. The project includes constructing a reservoir with a capacity of 4.5 million cubic meters and installing a 600 megawatt solar power park. What makes this project unique is the use of solar energy to power the pumps to fill the reservoir during peak hours. Then, the stored water of the reservoir is released through turbines to generate electricity during low-demand hours. This helps optimize electricity production and distribution. In short, the solar panels fill the reservoir while the hydropower is used to generate electricity.

Conclusion

Pumped-storage hydroelectricity is an innovative, cost-efficient renewable energy source that offers unprecedented flexibility. Its application in Madhya Pradesh’s Bhoj Metro project is a game changer in terms of optimally combining hydropower and solar power to produce electricity. This project’s success serves as an inspiration for similar ventures in other parts of the world. Going forward, we can expect to see more cost-effective, energy-efficient solutions for electricity generation thanks to this groundbreaking project in Madhya Pradesh.

news.n_description: Ajit Pawar, while addressing the rebel NCP faction at a meeting, on Wednesday told Sharad Pawar that it was time for him to retire. Pawar also said Sharad Pawar should hand over the reins of the NCP to him.

n_live_blog_content.n_title: Thunberg, 20, who became the face of young
n_live_blog_content.n_amp_description: Thunberg, 20, who became the face of young climate activists worldwide after staging weekly protests in front of the Swedish parliament, admitted during the court proceedings

n_offline_data.no_desc_withouthtml:
Ajit Pawar pulled no punches as he told estranged uncle Sharad Pawar that it was time for him to retire and hand over the reins of the NCP to him.

"You portrayed me as a villain in front of everyone. I still have deep respect for him (Sharad Pawar)," Ajit Pawar said.

"BJP leaders retire at 75. You can see the example of LK Advani and Murli Manohar Joshi. This allows the new generation to rise. You (Sharad Pawar) give us your blessings," Pawar said while addressing the rebel NCP faction at a meeting in a massive show of strength.

"You are 83, aren't you going to stop? Give us your blessings and we will pray that you live a long life," the deputy chief minister added.

Meanwhile, NCP working president Supriya Sule responded to Ajit Pawar's remark on Sharad Pawar's age and said, "Amitabh Bachchan is 82 and is still working."

"Disrespect us, but not our father (Sharad Pawar). This fight is against the BJP government, which is the most corrupt party in the country," Sule said in Mumbai.

"Some people believe that others have grown old and hence, they should just bless them. Why should they bless them? Ratan Tata is three years older than Saheb and leading the country's largest group," she added.

news.n_description: A student in Rajasthan's Kota who have been preparing for the JEE Mains examination committed suicide on Tuesday night. This is the fourth suicide in August in Kota.

n_offline_data.no_desc_withouthtml:
A student in Rajasthan's Kota died by suicide on Tuesday night. This becomes fourth suicide this month and 22th case this year, once again bringing the student deaths in the entrance coaching hub to the spotlight.

The 18-year-old boy, identified as Valmiki Jangid from Bihar’s Gaya, was studying in a coaching institute for the Joint Entrance Examination (JEE) Main examination for admission into Indian Institute of Technology (IIT).

Jangid was staying at Kota’s Mahavir Nagar area since last year.

The repeated student suicides in Kota have been a matter of concern. This year, as many as 22 coaching students have committed suicide so far.

These suicides have raised concerns about the mental health of students. The state government has announced several steps to address including a helpline for students in Kota.

news.n_title: Pulwama Attack 2019, everything about J&K terror attack on CRPF by terrorist Adil Ahmed Dar, Jaish-e-Mohammad
news.n_description: Congress asserted that despite the "relentless assault", Jawaharlal Nehru's legacy will live on for the world to see and he will continue to inspire generations to come.

n_offline_data.no_desc_withouthtml:
At least 40 Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF) paramilitary troopers were killed in the deadliest terror attack witnessed in three decades of Kashmir's insurgency. The surprise attack by a Jaish-e-Mohammed (JeM) suicide bomber left the nation in shock and anger while Prime Minister Narendra Modi gave security forces a freehand to strike back with equal force. On Thursday, Jaish bomber Adil Ahmed Dar, 20, rammed a SUV loaded with 350 kilograms of explosives into one of the buses -- carrying 35-40 troopers -- out of a 78-vehicle CRPF convoy. While 40 were killed in the attack, several injured personnel continue to battle for their lives.

  • International diplomatic reaction to Pulwama attack
  • Actions taken by India in aftermath of Pulwama attack

Even as the nation continues to bewail the death of soldiers killed in Pulwama, many including the grief-stricken family members of the ill-fated jawans have demanded strong action against the Pakistan-based terror outfit.

The heinous incident has united all political parties across the country while leaders from all over the world have condemned the dastardly attack; the United States even went on to the extent of warning Pakistan to not harbour terrorism.

At present, the security forces in the Valley are on high alert and subsequent operations have been launched to detain more suspects in connection with the attack.

Background of Pulwama attack

The situation in Kashmir has been tense since 2014 and there have been several deadly attacks on soldiers. In the last five years, Jammu and Kashmir has witnessed a 93 per cent rise in death of security personnel. A chunk of these attacks have occurred in Pulwama region of J&K. Data released by the government showed that the Valley has been witnessing regular terror attacks in the past five years.

Data released by the Ministry of Home Affairs showed there has been a sharp rise in terror activities including attacks between 2014 and 2018. It suggested that there has been a 176 per cent jump in terror attacks in the Valley during the period. The state witnessed over 1,700 terrorist activities (28/month) during the last five years, showed government data.

The data presented in Lok Sabha also show that there has been a sharp spike in terror activities since 2016. Between 2014 and 2018, a total of 1,315 people were killed in the state due to acts of terrorism, it revealed.

While several regions in the Valley have been affected by home-grown militants, the Pulwama district has seen a high volume of terror encounters. However, Thursday's attack that left 40 CRPF paramilitary troopers dead is the deadliest terror attack in the Valley in the last three decades of Kashmir's insurgency.

Time and exact place of Pulwama attack

The Pulwama terror attack occurred on February 14, 2019 when a 78-vehicle convoy was escorting over 2,500 CRPF jawans from Jammu to Srinagar. At around 3:30 pm, a Mahindra Scorpio SUV, packed with 350 kilograms of explosives rammed into one of the buses belonging to the convoy on the National Highway 44 at Lethipora near Avantipora town.

The surprise attack instantly blew up the bus, killing at least 40 personnel of the 76th Battalion while others continue to battle for their lives; the injured were immediately moved to the army base hospital in Srinagar.

Details of Pulwama attack

The Pulwama attack on Thursday (February 14) is the deadliest terror attack that has occurred in the Valley in the past three decades of militant activity in Kashmir.

The attack which killed at least 40 CRPF jawans was carried out by 20-year-old Adil Ahmed Dar, who was due to appear for his class 12 exams before he went missing, according to his parents.

While initial reports claimed that the attack was triggered by an IED explosion, it was later reported that Dar had rammed the explosive-laden SUV into one of the buses.

Pakistan-based terror outfit Jaish-e-Mohammed claimed responsibility for the attack and released a video of Dar, a resident of Kakapora who joined the group a year ago.

While Pakistan has denied any role in the attack, India has sent a stern warning to its neighbour while United States warned the nation to eradicate safe havens for terrorists. Many other countries have also condemned the dastardly incident that has left more than 40 families in anguish.

Political reaction of Pulwama attack

A huge political outcry was observed after the Pulwama terror attack. Prime Minister Narendra Modi not only condemned the attack on CRPF personnel but also gave security forces full freedom to retaliate against the heinous attack that killed 40 paramilitary troopers.

Congress president Rahul Gandhi, who was visibly emotional at a press event yesterday, said the entire Opposition stands in solidarity with the security forces and government. Former prime minister Manmohan Singh also condemned the attack and said such acts of terrorism cannot be tolerated.

A host of other ministers including Union Home Minister Rajnath Singh, Finance Minister Arun Jaitley and Railway Minister Piyush Goyal condemned the cowardly terror strike on security forces as well.

Not just political parties but prominent personalities from the field of art, entertainment and sports condemned the attack and demanded redemption.

International diplomatic reaction of Pulwama attack

Over 45 countries including the US and China reacted to the dastardly attack on CRPF jawans. The United States not only condemned the attack but also attacked Pakistan for harbouring terrorists.

It warned the nation to deny safe haven to terrorists or any terror outfits. Russian President Vladamir Putin sent condolences to Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his counterpart President Ram Nath Kovind.

France also condemned the attack and extended support to combat terror networks and cut their funding to prevent such cross-border attacks. While China expressed condolences and condemned the act of terror, it still did not change its stance on Masood Azhaar, who is the founder of Jaish-e-Mohammed.

Support also poured in from Australia, European Union, Nepal, Bhutan, Sri Lanka, Afghanistan, Maldives, Bangladesh and a host of other countries.

Actions taken by India in the aftermath of Pulwama attack

Indian administrators and security forces have gone into an overdrive after the devious attack on the CRPF convoy in Pulwama. Prime Minister Narendra Modi said the terror outfit has committed a huge mistake, adding that the sacrifice of the slain soldiers will not go in vain.

Modi said the security forces have been given a freehand to retaliate against the attack at any time they deem suitable.

Soon after a high-level Cabinet Committee on Security (CCS) meeting, Finance Minister Arun Jaitley declared that India is withdrawing "Most Favoured Nation" status to Pakistan.

The symbolic move will further cut trade ties between the two neighbouring nations. India has also launched a diplomatic offensive against Pakistan after the Pulwama terror attack. According to reports, India held a briefing for envoys of 25 countries including P5 nations, including US, China, Russia, UK and France.

Before the briefing, Foreign Secretary Vijay Gokhale summoned Pakistan High Commissioner to India Sohail Mahmood to his office and issued a very strong demarche over the attack.

news.n_description: This image of a child dressed in a bulletproof vest was originally part of an advertisement campaign.

n_offline_data.no_desc_withouthtml:
Gun violence, especially in schools, is an ongoing problem in the US. According to a Washington Post database, there have been at least 386 school shootings in the country since 1999, with more than 356,000 students having experienced gun violence in schools.

 

An image making the rounds on social media right now shows a child, purportedly from Texas, dressed in a bulletproof vest and helmet. According to those posting this picture, this was how the mother of the child prepared her for her first day of school. Uvalde in Texas witnessed a school shooting on May 24, 2022, during which 19 students and two teachers were killed and several others were injured.

A mom here in my county told me 3 weeks ago through tears that she purchased a bullet-proof insert to put in her daughter's backpack. She couldn't buy the one that stops AR-15 bullets because it weighed almost as much as her 5-year-old. This is our reality in Texas. pic.twitter.com/PHkek170sI

— 𝕁𝕒𝕪𝕟𝕖 🟧 🌈&👊🏾𝐚𝐥𝐥𝐲 #𝙗𝙖𝙣𝙉𝙍𝘼 🌊 (@EnneaGr8) May 6, 2023

"Jayne writes from Texas: A mom here in my county told me 3 weeks ago through tears that she purchased a bullet-proof insert to put in her daughter's backpack. She couldn't buy the one that stops AR-15 bullets because it weighed almost as much as her 5-year-old. This is our reality in Texas," read one such viral post. The archived version of a similar post can be seen here.

India Today Fact found that the image in question was part of an advertisement — it doesn’t show a real incident. 

Our Probe

A reverse search of the viral image led us to a report ( http://bitly.ws/PLDk ) from August 16, 2022, that featured this image in a video. The headline read: "Texas child shown in back-to-school advertisement wearing body armour." The report mentioned that a group of mothers in Texas commissioned this advert. 

Reportedly, this advertisement was curated to make a stand against Texas Governor Greg Abbott after the incident at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, that happened just before the summer break. Per a report from Chron, published on August 17, 2022, a group called "Mothers Against Greg Abbott" was formed before the summer vacation was over and children started to return to their classrooms. 

A search with subsequent keywords took us to a YouTube channel named "Mothers Against Greg Abbott," where we found the original 30-second-long video featuring the frame in question around the 18-second timestamp. 

The description of the video reads, "Kids all over Texas and the United States are getting ready for back to school, but something feels different this year. Our kids are not soldiers, regardless of what the extreme right thinks. Whether you're a Republican, a Democrat, or neither, it's time to come together and demand meaningful gun safety reform now. Please go here to donate to help us get these ads on the air." This made it clear that it was an ad campaign. 

However, we also found news articles that reported how a mother created a “bulletproof” back-to-school dress. While the dress wasn't bulletproof, it was designed to make a statement.    

Therefore, it is safe to conclude that the claim of a mother sending her child with a bulletproof outfit in Texas is not true.

news.n_description: A petition has been moved in Supreme Court seeking to stop the rallies announced by Vishva Hindu Parishad (VHP) and Bajrang Dal in Delhi-NCR following the Nuh communal violence. test kicker

n_offline_data.no_desc_withouthtml:
A petition has been moved in the Supreme Court seeking to stop the rallies announced by Vishva Hindu Parishad (VHP) and Bajrang Dal in Delhi-NCR following the Nuh communal violence. Senior Advocate CU Singh filed an urgent petition before the Supreme Court to stop the rallies. Advocate CU Singh told the Chief Justice that he requested an early hearing from Justice Aniruddha Bose, but he referred him to the CJI.

Mentioning it a volatile situation, the petitioner said that “it is an urgent matter”. CJI then said the court will pass order immediately. The Chief Justice said, “We are sitting in the Constitution Bench. We have made arrangements for the quick hearing of urgent cases. Go to the mentioning registrar.” So, the case has been adjourned for a while. The mentioning registrar will list it for a speedy hearing.

n_offline_data.no_desc_withouthtml: A film – also called a movie, motion picture, moving picture, picture, photoplay or (slang) flick – is a work of visual art that simulates experiences and otherwise communicates ideas, stories, perceptions, feelings, beauty, or atmosphere through the use of moving images. These images are generally accompanied by sound and, more rarely, other sensory stimulations.[1] The word "cinema", short for cinematography, is often used to refer to filmmaking and the film industry, and the art form that is the result of it.

news.n_description: In a major accident in Trikut Pahar in Deoghar on Sunday, at least 10 people were injured and about 70 tourists still trapped on the ropeway as rescue operations are underway.

n_offline_data.no_desc_withouthtml:
At least 10 tourists were injured after some cable cars on a ropeway collided with each other at Trikut Pahar close to Baba Baidyanath Temple in Deoghar, Jharkhand on Sunday.

According to reports, about 70 people are still trapped in 19 trolleys in the ropeway. The National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) team have been deployed for the rescue. Meanwhile, the top officials of the district administration have reached Trikut.

Trolleys of the Trikoot ropeway located in the Mohanpur police station area collided with each other, according to reports. Women and small children are also among the injured. Hundreds of tourists had arrived on Sunday to visit the temple and roam around on the occasion of Ramnavami.

The incident has been confirmed by Superintendent of Police (SP) Subhash Chandra Jat and Deputy Commissioner (DC) Manjunath Bhaijantri.

Also Read Flipkart Big Billion Days sale date revealed, iPhone 13 and iPhone 12 to get discounted

A tourist told India Today that when his trolley was going up, at the same time, other trolleys were coming down and the accident occurred due to the trolleys coming in contact with each other.

DC Manjunath Bhaijantri said that at present the ropeway is closed. The injured has been sent to Deoghar Sadar Hospital for treatment. Meanwhile, the work of evacuating the rest of the tourists is still going on.

Jharkhand Tourism says that Trikut ropeway is India's highest vertical ropeway with a maximum lens angle of 44 degrees. The ropeway, situated around 20 km from Baba Baidyanath Temple, is around 766-metres-long, while the hill is 392-metres-high.

There are 25 cabins on the ropeway. Four people can sit in each cabin. The ropeway manager and other employees fled the spot after the incident.

Dreamfolks Services IPO: The initial public offer (IPO) of Dreamfolks Services will open on August 24 (Wednesday). The firm, which is India's largest airport service aggregator platform, plans to raise Rs 562 crore. The IPO will close on August 26. The company is offering its shares in a price band of Rs 308 to Rs 326 per share. The lot size of Dreamfolks Services IPO is 46 shares for which one will have to spend Rs 14,996.

A retail individual investor can submit bids for up to 13 lots or 598 shares by spending Rs 1,94,948. Equirus Capital Private Limited and Motilal Oswal Investment Advisors Pvt Ltd are the lead managers of the IPO. The allotment of shares will be done on September 1 and they are likely to be listed on BSE and NSE on September 6.
The company will not directly receive any proceeds from the offer and the entire proceeds of the IPO will be received by the selling shareholders.

Alia Bhatt’s recent comments in an interview has triggered a boycott call for her upcoming film, Brahmastra, with actor-husband Ranbir Kapoor. This comes after boycott calls marred the performance of one of the most anticipated movies, Aamir Khan’s Laal Singh Chaddha as well as Akshay Kumar’s Raksha Bandhan. The latest boycott call for Brahmastra does not bode well for an industry that has delivered a string of big-budget flops. The boycott call also raises questions on Ranbir Kapoor’s capability of delivering a hit, following the dismal box office performance of Shamshera.

The calls to boycott Ayan Mukerji-directorial Brahmastra were revived after Bhatt, in an interview with Mid-Day said, “I can’t keep defending myself verbally. And if you don’t like me, don’t watch me. I can’t help it.” She was responding to a question on how trolling – she has been the subject of some vicious trolling –  impacts her.She had further stated that it is not something she can do anything about since people have something or the other to say, but she hopes to prove to them with her movies that she is actually worth the space she occupies. She said that she does feel bad but she hopes to shut such conversations with her movies.esla and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk’s college sweetheart Jennifer Gwynne has auctioned off her photos with Musk off late.  These photos show Musk as a 20-year-old college student having fun around the University of Pennsylvania campus. Gwynne, who currently lives with her stepson in South Carolina, is selling these photos via RR Auction to raise money for her stepson’s tuition fee.

 
 
 
 
View this post on Instagram
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

A post shared by India Today (@indiatoday)

 

Sharing a picture of Musk as a 23-year-old at the University of Pennsylvania, Gwynne said, “Elon was usually very reserved, but occasionally he would just get very silly and want me to laugh along with him. So I decided to document him actually smiling.”She said their romance was sweet but there was not much affection or ‘PDA’ as Musk largely resisted it. It was during this time that Musk’s mother and supermodel Maye Musk and his siblings had got to know about his plans to make electric vehicles.

She also said, “Timeline note here– Elon talked about electric cars being the way of the future back in 1994. He said [EV] was going to be [at the] forefront of the movement and I never doubted that he would be there – he was so matter-of-fact and so sure that electric cars were coming. So, honestly, for the last 25 years, I knew Tesla was going to work, that it was going to be successful. There is something so very infectious about Elon’s confidence and clarity.”

After graduating from Penn with BA in physics and Bachelor of Science degree in economics from Wharton school, Musk went to Stanford University for PhD in materials science. Musk left Stanford after two days to launch his first start-up amid the internet boom.

news.n_title: OnePlus 10 Pro in pics: Looks different and quite powerful
news.n_description: OnePlus 10 Pro is already up for sale in India from April 5. If you are interested to purchase the phone, here is a closer look at what it offers. The 10 Pro goes against the likes of the iPhone 13, the Samsung Galaxy S22 series, iQOO 9 Pro and more.

photos.np_caption: The OnePlus 10 Pro starts at a price of Rs 66,999 for the base 8GB RAM + 128GB storage version. The top-end model comes packed with 12GB RAM + 256GB internal storage and is priced at Rs 71,999.

OnePlus 10 Pro offers a big screen, which may not feel very comfortable to use all day. It packs a 6.7 inch AMOLED display, 3216 X 1440 pixels screen resolution, 120hz refresh rate, and Corning Gorilla Glass protection on top.

The OnePlus 10 Pro camera performance has improved a lot when compared to the predecessor OnePlus 9 Pro. It includes a triple rear camera system consisting of a 48-megapixel Sony IMX789 image sensor coupled with a 50-megapixel ultrawide angle lens, and an 8-megapixel telephoto lens.
The OnePlus 10 Pro offers an all-day backup. It is backed by a 5000mAh battery with support for an 80W SUPERVOOC charging adapter in the box.

In terms of performance, the OnePlus 10 Pro offers top-notch specifications. It is powered by Qualcomm's Snapdragon 8 Gen 1 system-on-chip paired with Adreno 730, 12GB LPDDR5 RAM, and 256GB UFS 3.1 internal storage.

So, honestly, for the last 25 years, I knew Tesla was going to work, that it was going to be successful. There is something so very infectious about Elon’s confidence and clarity.”After graduating from Penn with BA in physics and Bachelor of Science degree in economics from Wharton school, Musk went to Stanford University for PhD in materials science. Musk left Stanford after two days to launch his first start-up amid the internet boom.

news.n_title: Oktoberfest is back! World's largest beer festival returns to Germany after 2 years | Pics
news.n_slug: Oktoberfest is back! World's largest beer festival returns to Germany after 2 years | Pics

photos.np_caption: Oktoberfest beer festival returned to Germany after a gap of two years.
People run onto the festival ground on the opening day of the 187th Oktoberfest beer festival in Munich, Germany.
A hunter poses with an eagle during the traditional costume parade of the Oktoberfest beer festival.
The festival is celebrated from mid- or late-September to the first Sunday in October.
Oktoberfest beer festival returned to Germany after a gap of two years.
Oktoberfest is the world's largest beer festival.

news.n_title: Rangers concerned deep water port could threaten Congo's sea turtles | Pics
news.n_description: A new concern is emerging in the form of a port in Congo, which the government says will bring jobs and lower the cost of imports, but that rangers worry will further endanger them.

photos.np_caption: Hundreds of freshly hatched turtles are released onto the beach.
"The problem we have at the moment is that to really protect them, we need to protect the coast," a ranger said.
Now a new concern is emerging in the form of a port, which the government says will bring jobs and lower the cost of imports, but that rangers worry will further endanger them.
They bring the eggs to a hatching centre where they are incubated for eight weeks.
Rising sea levels and erosion have consumed almost a quarter of the turtle's nesting grounds, the rangers estimate.
Each year park rangers scour the beaches of Democratic Republic of Congo's vanishing coastline for turtle nests.

news.n_title: With elections afoot, French candidates battle it out on socks | Pics
news.n_description: Maxime Lemersre, owner of Chaussettes and compagnie shop, displays socks decorated with the faces of the top candidates at his shop.

photos.np_caption: 2022 French presidential election is just around the corner.
Maxime Lemersre, owner of Chaussettes and compagnie shop, displays socks decorated with the faces of the top candidates at his shop.
“We are becoming the first physical polling institute in France,” says Maxime Lemersre.

The Lille-based brand recently launched a collection of socks featuring seven presidential candidates: Anne Hidalgo, Yannick Jadot, Marine Le Pen, Emmanuel Macron, Jean-Luc Mélenchon, Valérie Pécresse and Éric Zemmour.
The first round of the 2022 French presidential election will be held on April 10.

news.n_title: From citizens to refugees, exodus from Ukraine continues amid Russian invasion | Pics
news.n_description: As Russian invasion continues, Ukrainian people have turned from citizens to refugees seeking shelter in neighbouring countries.

photos.np_caption: Millions of people have been displaced since Putin declared war more than a month ago.
Makeshift tents have been set up for refugees in countries willing to offer a shelter.
Ukrainians are trying everything possible to escape war.
While some took train, others boarded buses and some even left on foot in an attempt to cross the border as firing continues.
As Russian invasion continues, Ukrainian people have turned from citizens to refugees seeking shelter in neighbouring countries.
More than one month on, Russia still continues to bomb Ukrainian cities as forces advance.

news.n_title: Anushka Ranjan gets a special dress designed by Manish Malhotra ahead of her BFF Alia Bhatt’s wedding to Ranbir Kapoor

The countdown for Alia Bhatt and Ranbir Kapoor’s wedding has started as the couple is all set to tie the knot on April 14. Alia’s uncle, Robin Bhatt, confirmed the news and also informed that the mehendi ceremony would take place on April 13.

news.n_title: Your Weekend Planner April 8
news.n_description: There's Ranbir Kapoor and Alia Bhatt ki shaadi. Psst, saas-to-be Neetu Kapoor just reacted to the wedding. It IS happening, guys. Brace yourself this Thursday, April 14.

n_offline_data.no_desc_withouthtml:
Dear Reader,

Another week, another Bollywood shaadi. It's a good thing we are a Bollywood and cricket-crazy nation, for we have both aplenty this week. IPL is on, and yours truly is Team KKR - where Bollywood and cricket come together, and take us in with Shah Rukh Khan's open arms. And then, on the other hand, there's Ranbir Kapoor and Alia Bhatt ki shaadi. Psst, saas-to-be Neetu Kapoor just reacted to the wedding. It IS happening, guys. Brace yourself this Friday, April 14.

Till then, we'll tell all about Ranbir and Alia's wedding guest list, their respective bachelor's and bachelorette parties, the khandani necklace that Alia will inherit from Neetu, the endorsement deals this new Power Couple on the block is getting, and more. Phew! Kapoor Khandaan ki shaadi hai, bhai. Baratiyon ka swagat nahi karoge?

Now, if shaadi stuff is too much for you, and we totally get it if it is, turn your gaze towards Shashi Tharoor. For his gaze is breaking the internet. A video, shared by Twitter user Farrago Abdullah, shows Tharoor speaking to Supriya Sule while former Jammu and Kashmir chief minister Farooq Abdullah delivers his speech. Farrago, indeed.

Need more time off from the wedding saga? Fix yourself a Chicken Cobb Salad this week and flip through the pages of Neverwhere by Neil Gaiman, then put it down and start watching Gullak Season 3 on SonyLIV. Take all the me-time you can get this weekend, for next week is going to be madder. Countdown to the Ranbir-Alia shaadi...

3...2...1...

See you next Friday.

WHAT’S TRENDING?

Kab hai Ranbir Kapoor aur Alia Bhatt Ki shaadi? All this speculation around the next big Bollywood wedding kept most of us busy. However, there have been some noteworthy developments throughout this week besides the upcoming wedding of the year that you should know about. For starters, Mumbai civic body BMC announcing India’s first case of the XE variant of coronavirus. The news gave us a real scare. However, central government sources disagreed with the findings, adding that top officials of the Centre’s research body INSACOG will re-examine the sample in question.

Meanwhile, Congress MP Shashi Tharoor sent the internet into an overdrive after a clip of him interacting with NCP leader Supriya Sule in the Lok Sabha went viral. Tharoor was seen leaning over his chair to talk to Sule while former Jammu and Kashmir chief minister Farooq Abdullah delivered his speech. The Thiruvananthapuram MP’s smiling face and leaning posture during the interaction triggered a meme-fest on social media.

It was a great speech by Farooq Abdullah. Must listen for everyone. @ShashiTharoor pic.twitter.com/STQe0yulxG

— Farrago Abdullah (@abdullah_0mar) April 6, 2022

Also, how can we forget Pat Cummins’s absolutely swashbuckling performance during Mumbai Indians vs Kolkata Knight Riders match in IPL 2022. Cummins equalled the record for the fastest half-century in IPL when he got to the milestone off only 14 balls.

In other news, it was a big year for India at the Grammys with Ricky Kej and Falguni Shah winning awards in two separate categories. Indian-American singer Falguni Shah won the Best Children’s Music Album award at the Grammys, while Ricky Kej won the award in the Best New Age Album category. In his exclusive interview with IndiaToday.in, Kej mentioned that he wants to work with music maestro AR Rahman.

SOMETHING TO MAKE YOU SMILE

This video of a little girl trying to look like her pet dog by applying makeup will make you laugh hard till your stomach hurts. So cute, right?

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Good News Movement (@goodnews_movement)

Also, the internet cannot get enough of this video where a grandfather sings What a Wonderful World for his grandson with down syndrome to make his birthday special.

DON’T FORGET TO WORK OUT

Milind Soman never fails to set workout goals for his Instagram followers. In a recent post, Milind shared some easy tips to stay healthy and fit. And here’s something Milind said that you must read, “There is a famous quote from almost 300 years ago 'if you don't find time to exercise, you will have to find time to be sick' and this is even more relevant today.”

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Milind Usha Soman (@milindrunning)

In fact, if you aren’t a gym-person, Milind can help you with an alternative. The 56-year-old actor exercises every day for 15-20 minutes to avoid getting weaker and Surya Namaskar, in his opinion, is the best exercise for overall fitness. Why don’t you try?

WHAT’S ON MY PLATE?

To beat the summer heat, we have a quick recipe of a delicious Chicken Cobb Salad that you will simply enjoy. Do try this weekend.

Chicken Cobb Salad. (Photo: Getty Images)

HOW TO MAKE CHICKEN COBB SALAD?

To make chicken cobb salad, you will need - 450 grams of boneless and skinless chicken breast, 4 hard-boiled eggs, green lettuce leaves torn into bite-sized pieces, 6 baby tomatoes quartered, 1 cup of sliced cucumber and 1 thinly sliced avocado.

For the dressing, you will need- 1 tablespoon of mustard, 2 tablespoons of minced onion, lemon juice, half a teaspoon each of salt and sugar, pepper and olive oil.

For the dressing, put everything together in a bowl and combine. Mix in the olive oil until the dressing has emulsified. Set aside. Next, rub the chicken breasts with olive oil and season with salt and pepper. Heat up oil in a pan and cook the chicken on the first side for 3-4 minutes. Flip the chicken and cover the pan with a lid to allow it to cook through for 7-10 minutes. Allow it to rest for 5-10 minutes.

Arrange the lettuce in a large bowl and add the cooked chicken, quartered hard-boiled eggs, tomatoes, cucumber and avocado. Pour the dressing. Mix and enjoy.

FASHIONABLY YOURS

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Alia Bhatt (@aliaabhatt)

Alia Bhatt and Ranbir Kapoor are set to get married and fans cannot keep calm. The couple is expected to tie the knot on April 15. Now, it is no secret that bride-to-be Alia is a fashionista. The Highway actress boasts of a quirky collection of outfits that are just perfect for a day out on the beach. So, in this week's Fashion Friday, we take a look at Alia’s favourite beach outfits that we would love to steal.

FROM THE BOOKSHELF

Neverwhere by Neil Gaiman

Neverwhere by Neil Gaiman

Neverwhere is a fantasy story that follows Richard Mayhew, a normal Londoner, whose world quite literally turns upside down when he encounters a girl named Door and discovers an entirely different London beneath the city that he knows.

This story is adventurous, magical, dark, and witty and Gaiman’s wry humour is a breath of fresh air. The novel is a brilliant piece of fantasy and will linger in your mind days after turning the last page.

MOVIES AND MAGIC

Fantastic Beasts: The Secrets of Dumbledore rules theatres this week. That is if RRR cuts it a slice of the box-office pie. Potterheads are sorted this week. But what about good ol' masala movie janta? Bas ek week ka intezaar, for next Friday, Rocky Bhai returns with KGF: Chapter 2. Uff, we just got goosebumps! Shahid Kapoor-starrer Jersy also arrives in theatres next week. Spoilt for choice, no?

So, does that mean this week is going to be bland? Nope. Ranbir Kapoor-Alia Bhatt ki shaadi hai na to add all the tarka you need. The lovebirds are getting hitched on April 14, and the mehendi, sangeet will begin on April 13. Right now, news of RaAlia ki shaadi has taken over our social media feed. Their wedding and Mumbai reception guest list, their wedding outfits, the precise date the two started dating, the Kapoor Khandan necklace Alia will inherit from saas-to-be Neetu - we have you covered on all fronts.

While movies takes a break - but not the magic, though - OTT offers a platter of new stuff. Taanakkaran is streaming on Disney+ Hotstar. Do catch it, our review gives it a thumbs-up. Then, the cute Mishra family returns with Season 3 of Gullak on SonyLIV. Naye kisse, wohi kirdaar, wohi pyaar.

For more about this week's OTT releases, here's our OTT section.

ON YOUR OTT SCREENS

ON NETFLIX

What to watch: Dasvi

You will like it if you liked: 3 Idiots

Abhishek Bachchan, Yami Gautam and Nimrat Kaur’s Dasvi releases on Netflix on April 7. It is a social comedy helmed by Tushar Jalota. Dasvi is based on the life of an uneducated politician, named Ganga Ram Chaudhary who wants to appear for his 10th examination from jail.

What to watch: Metal Lords

You will like it if you liked: The Game of Thrones

Game of Thrones creators David Benioff and DB Weiss's latest offering Metal Lords will release on Netflix on April 8. It is written and produced by DB Weiss and directed by Peter Sollett. The cast includes Isis Hainsworth, Sufe Bradshaw, Noah Urrea, Analesa Fisher, Michelle Fang, Phelan Davis and Joe Manganiello.

What to watch: The In Between

You will like it if you liked: Kissing Booth

The In Between story revolves around a broken hearted teenager. It stars Netflix’s The Kissing Booth famed Joey King as Tessa in the role of the protagonist. It premieres on April 8. The film was initially released on February 11, 2022, for the US audience on Paramount+, and is now releasing for the international audience.

What to watch: Return to Space

You will like it if you liked: Star Trek

Return to Space is a Netflix documentary film that will be available for streaming on April 7. Directed by Jimmy Chin and Elizabeth Chai Vasarhelyi, it tells the story of Elon Musk and SpaceX mission that sent NASA astronauts back to the International Space Station.

What to watch: Etharkkum Thunindhavan

You will like it if you liked: Jai Bhim

Suriya's Etharkkum Thunindhavan, directed by Pandiraj, is a film loosely based on the Pollachi sexual harassment case. The film was released in theatres on March 10 and received great reviews. Read our review here. You can watch it on Sun NXT as well.

ON SONYLIV

What to watch: Gullak season 3

You will like it if you liked: Gullak season 1 and 2

The show revolves around a North-Indian family, the Mishras. It speaks of the everyday experiences of a small town, middle-class Indian household. It releases on April 7.

ON APPLE TV

What to watch: Pinecone and Pony

You will like it if you liked: Disenchantment

The story follows Pinecone and her pony and their adventures in the medieval world. It releases on Apple TV on April 8.

ON AMAZON PRIME VIDEO

What to watch: All the Old Knives

You will like it if you liked: Body of Lies

Chris Pine and Thandie Newton star in All the Old Knives, directed by Janus Metz. The espionage thriller is based on the novel of the same title by Steinhauer. The story delves into a deep issue within the CIA, when an agent leaks sensitive information which costs the lives of more than 100 people. The task is to root out the mole.

ON AMAZON MINITV

What to watch: Murder in Agonda

You will like it if you liked: Aranyak

Shriya Pilgaonkar and Aasif Khan-starrer Murder in Agonda is an engaging whodunit story set in a Goan village where peace is disrupted by the murder of an old woman. A brother-sister duo set out to solve the crime as the inspector and a forensic expert. But, secrets are dangerous and the truth is beyond their imagination.

ON ZEE5

What to watch: Abhay Season 3

You will like it if you liked: Abhay

The much-awaited third season of one of the most popular thriller series, Abhay, is here. Directed by Ken Gosh, it stars Kunal Khemu as SP Abhay Pratap Singh who is determined to catch a notorious serial killer. Vijay Raaz, Rahul Dev, Asha Negi and Tanuj Virwani also feature in Abhay Season 3.

ON DISNEY+HOTSTAR

What to watch: Taanakaran

You will like it if you liked: Vikram Vedha

Written and directed by Tamizh, Taanakaran is a gripping police-drama starring Vikram Prabhu, Anjali Nair, Lal and MS Bhaskar in lead roles. The film talks about the struggles faced by young police trainees at a training camp. Vikram Prabhu will be seen as an aggressive trainee who questions his superior.

What to watch: Moon Knight

You will like it if you liked: Supernatural

Moon Knight's second episode released this week. It features Oscar Isaac essaying the role of Marc Spector. The Marvel web series is based on a superhero who has an identity disorder. The first season will have Moon Knight grappling with a mystery involving the Egyptian Gods.

ON DISCOVERY+

What to watch: Serving the Hamptons

You will like it if you liked: Too Hot To Handle

Serving the Hamptons is based on the glamorous lives of the hottest staff of an 'IT' Southampton restaurant. From steamy romance to bitter arguments, you will find every possible reality show drama on this show. But the question is, will the restaurant employees make it a profitable summer season? You can find it out now as the show has been streaming from April 7.

What to watch: The Repair Shop (season 5)

You will like it if you liked: Inside The Factory

At a workshop in the British countryside, tattered, old artefacts, and antiques are given a new life. A crew of talented craftsmen blow life into old objects.

ON MX PLAYER

What to watch: Forever Buddies 2

You will like it if you liked: Life Sahi Hai

Starring Jaytesh Calpakkam, Jikki Nair, Sivaraman and Arjun Manohar, Forever Buddies 2 is a Tamil show, also available in Hindi. The show deals with how people belonging to the post-millennial world deal with their romantic problems. The web show has been streaming from April 7.

ON YOUR TV SCREENS

What to watch: DID Li'l Masters 5

Where to watch: Zee TV, 9 pm (Saturday and Sunday)

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by ZEE TV (@zeetv)

In the upcoming season of DID Li'l Masters 5, contestant Sagar Varpe will be seen impressing the audience and the judges with his dance moves. He will be dancing to Mukkala Mukabula Laila. Judge Remo D'Souza will also join him on the stage.

What to watch: The Kapil Sharma Show

Where to watch: Sony TV, 9.30 pm (Saturday and Sunday)

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Kapil Sharma (@kapilsharma)

The Dasvi cast - Abhishek Bachchan, Nimrat Kaur and Yami Gautam, will be seen on The Kapil Sharma Show this Saturday, April 9. They will be seen sharing interesting anecdotes from the film, which released on Netflix on April 7.

What to watch: India's Got Talent 9

Where to watch: Sony TV, 8 pm (Saturday and Sunday)

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Sony Entertainment Television (@sonytvofficial)

This weekend, India's Got Talent will be high on entertainment and emotion. The contestants will give a tribute to the show's judges Kirron Kher, Shilpa Shetty Kundra, Badshah and Manoj Muntashir, on Saturday in the Judges Special episode. A performance by Mumbai’s Demolition Crew for Shilpa Shetty will make her emotional. This weekend, the talent hunt show will be selecting its Top 7 contestants as it nears its finale.

What to watch: KBC 14 registration question

Where to watch: Sony TV, 9 pm (Saturday)

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Sony Entertainment Television (@sonytvofficial)

The first question of Kaun Banega Crorepati 14 will be aired on April 9. The popular reality show will soon return on Sony TV with Amitabh Bachchan as host.

news.n_title: Bride-to-be Alia's quirky beach outfits that we want to steal. On Fashion Friday
news.n_description: From flowy dresses to vibrant bikinis, Alia Bhatt has it all and carries everything with utmost style. So, in this week's Fashion Friday, we take a look at Alia’s favourite beach outfits that we would love to steal.

n_offline_data.no_desc_withouthtml:
Alia Bhatt and Ranbir Kapoor are set to get married and fans cannot keep calm. The countdown for their wedding has begun and people are waiting with bated breath. The couple is expected to tie the knot on April 15 and the other wedding festivities are supposed to begin from April 13.

Now, it is no secret that bride-to-be Alia is a fashionista. Her wardrobe boasts of some gorgeous western wear and we can’t even begin to tell how much we love her ethnics. Apart from that, the Highway actress has a quirky collection of outfits that are just perfect for a day out on the beach.

From flowy dresses to vibrant bikinis, the diva has it all and carries everything with utmost style. So, in this week's Fashion Friday, we take a look at Alia’s favourite beach outfits that we would love to steal.

PRETTY IN PINK

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Alia Bhatt (@aliaabhatt)

A comfortable dress goes a long way and Alia definitely knows that. The actress looked pretty watching a sunset at a beach. What did she wear, you ask? Well, she opted for a bright pink mini dress that featured a racerback. She ditched her makeup and accessorised minimally with her favourite pair of golden hoops. She left her hair loose and flashed her cute, dimpled smile for the camera.

FEELING THE GOOD BLUES

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Alia Bhatt (@aliaabhatt)

For another fun beach outing with sister Shaheen Bhatt, Alia sizzled in a blue bikini. The sexy piece consisted of a strapless bikini with a white thong, which complemented her toned figure perfectly. For her makeup, the Gangubai Kathiawadi actress opted for a dewy base, a dab of mascara and a hint of pink blush. She left her hair loose and we are so in love.

NEON ALERT

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Alia Bhatt (@aliaabhatt)

To ring in her best friend Akansha Ranjan Kapoor’s birthday, Alia looked gorgeous in a pink neon bikini that she paired with a skirt. The skirt was in a baby-pink shade and the bikini featured a quirky strappy back. She tied her hair in a low bun and accessorised with tinted sunglasses and golden hoops. We like!

HAT FOR KEEPS

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Alia Bhatt (@aliaabhatt)

Alia styled her blue bikini with a huge black hat for another one of her beach outings. The cool accessory added to the whole vibe of summers and we are definitely taking notes. The diva kept her makeup minimal with some blush and pink lipstick. “Smile, dream, shine,” she captioned the post.

TECHNICOLOUR!

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Alia Bhatt (@aliaabhatt)

Alia completely stole our hearts when she stepped out in a multi-coloured dress for a day at the beach. The vibrant number featured shades of blue, yellow, pink and orange and the diva looked super-cute in it. She opted for a pair of her trusted golden hoops to accessorise and kept her makeup minimal with a dewy base and pink lipstick.

UP MLC polls | Highlights
news.n_description:
Voting for 36 seats in the Uttar Pradesh Legislative Council is being held on Saturday from 8 am to 4 pm.  Ninety-five candidates are in the fray in the biennial poll. The voters in the election are village pradhans, members and chairman of block development councils, members and chairman of Zila panchayat, corporators in urban areas and MLAs and MPs. 
In the 100-member Legislative Council, the BJP has 34 MLCs, the Samajwadi Party 17 and the Bahujan Samaj Party four. The Congress, Apna Dal (Sonelal) and NISHAD party have one member each in the House.
The votes will be counted on April 12. Follow IndiaToday.in for LIVE updates.

n_live_blog_content.n_title: Over 60 per cent turnout recorded till noon in UP MLC polls
n_live_blog_content.n_amp_description:
Over 60 per cent turnout was recorded in the first four hours of polling in the Uttar Pradesh Legislative Council biennial elections on Saturday, officials said.

According to the Election Commission of India, an average of 60.92 per cent polling was recorded in the state till 12 noon, with Pratapgarh registering the lowest turnout at 50.30 per cent, while Agra-Firozabad constituency recorded the highest turnout at 73.81 per cent.

news.n_title: Amit Shah’s ‘Nehru’s blunders’ on Kashmir remark leads to Congress walkout
news.n_description: Union Home Minister Amit Shah's remarks on Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru led to several Congress MPs walking out of Parliament on Wednesday.

n_offline_data.no_desc_withouthtml:
Several Opposition MPs walked out of Parliament during Union Home Minister Amit Shah's remarks on Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru. Shah held the former Prime Minister responsible for the issue of Pakistan-Occupied Kashmir (POK).

"The problem of Pakistan Occupied Kashmir occurred because of Pandit Nehru. Otherwise, that part would have belonged to Kashmir. Nehruji was responsible for POK," Shah said.

“Nehru ji said it was his mistake. It was not a mistake. It was a blunder to lose so much land of this country," Shah added.

According to the Home Minister, Jammu and Kashmir suffered due to two "blunders"by Nehru - announcing a ceasefire and taking the Kashmir issue to the United Nations.
